case_vignette: A 66-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of a new skin lesion on his hand. He is concerned because the lesion has grown rapidly over the previous 2 weeks. He endorses traumatizing the area and notes that there was some bleeding. His past medical history is significant for chronic renal failure for which he received a renal transplant 5 years prior, as well as multiple surgeries for skin cancers. His current medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, prednisone, tacrolimus, and mycophenolate mofetil. Physical exam is notable for a 2 x 2.5 cm nodular lesion of the dorsal hand (Figure A).
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm here because I have a new lump on the back of my hand that's been growing quickly over the last two weeks.
How old are you?
I am 66 years old.
Is the lump painful or tender to the touch?
The description doesn't mention whether the lump is painful or tender.
Does the lump have any color changes or bleeding?
Yes, it bled after I injured it.
Do you have a history of excessive sun exposure or sunburns?
The information I have doesn't say anything about my sun exposure or sunburn history.
Have you noticed any changes in the skin around the lump, like skin thickening or a change in pigmentation?
The description I gave doesn't include any details about changes in the skin around the lump.
Does the lump appear to be filled with fluid or is it a solid mass?
The lump on my hand is solid.
Is there any history of skin cancer in your family?
The information I have doesn't include any details about my family history of skin cancer.
Are you currently taking any medication?
Yes, I am taking aspirin, atorvastatin, prednisone, tacrolimus, and mycophenolate mofetil.
Have you had any organ transplants or are you being treated for an autoimmune disease?
Yes, I had a kidney transplant 5 years ago.
Final Diagnosis: Post-transplant cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
